Rating 4 out of 5 stars!

Review title: Campy,vampy and violent,the mutt's nuts in every respect.
Review_body: I saw this brilliantly entertaining movie in a multiplex back in 1996 and it appears regularly on UK TV channels so you have absolutely no excuse for not watching out for it in the listing mags.Even on a super - size HD Plasma surround sound model you cannot remotely approach the impact of the theatre showing,but those who were unable to catch it first time round will get at least an idea of what I am raving about. "The Long Kiss Goodnight" is a supercharged Jekyll and Hyde story with Miss G.Davis absolutely outstanding as the whitebread schoolteacher with a very funky alter ego. Former Jekylls range from the outstanding (Lon Chaney) to the mediocre (James Nesbitt) but none can match Miss Davis for her reliance on subtle facial changes to suggest her possession by the second of her dual personalities and the sheer physical and mental agility she gradually acquires that surprises even herself. She hires threadbare ex - cop/jailbird Mr S.L.Jackson to delve into her background and he opens a Pandora's Box.Her past is filled with double and triple crosses,assassinations and rogue CIA agents.As the dauntless pair proceed to confront her demons they are opposed by a series of remorseless and seemingly indestructible foes. These are the bare bones of a consistently exciting and entertaining movie that affronted the critics on its release presumably for daring to show Miss Davis as a sexually confident woman ready and able to commit murder and mayhem - previously strictly a male province. "The Long Kiss Goodnight" is a high energy movie replete with car crashes and a huge body count;it is not for one moment to be taken seriously,nor was it meant to be.It is,however,one of the great action movies of the 1990s,and I await its every reappearance with eager anticipation.

Review title: This movie isn't perfect but it's a helluva lot of fun
Review_body: The Long Kiss Goodnight (1996) is a movie in my DVD collection that I recently watched on Tubi. The storyline follows a regular every day housewife that's married, has a little girl and seems perfectly normal. In her history she suffered amnesia and shortly after waking up she started this storybook life. One day her past starts coming back to her and she starts becoming mean and ruthless. She decides to take a break from mommy life and work with a private investigator to uncover her past which may stir some unexpected demons. This movie is directed by Renny Harlin (Devil's Pass) and stars Geena Davis (Beetlejuice), Samuel L. Jackson (Pulp Fiction), Brian Cox (Troy) and David Morse (Green Mile). The storyline for this picture is fun to watch unfold and is presented in a clever and stylish fashion. The acting is out of this world as Davis and Jackson really nail their performances. The script is also clever and contains a nice blend of humor and intensity and also helps you relate to the characters. The action scenes, shootouts, torture scenes, car chases and explosions are excellent. The soundtrack is also great. This movie isn't perfect but it's a helluva lot of fun. I'd score this an 8.5/10 and strongly recommend it.

Review title: Director Renny Harlin took cinema for a 'family business' by making "The Long Kiss Goodnight'.
Review_body: As the art and craft of film making is family business for many people, there is nothing wrong in making a film with your wife in a leading role but it should make some sense.One is bound to fail if the film does not convey in a positive manner what it intends to show.On a global level this is a golden mantra for all talented directors. As a film which is short of intelligent ideas,'The Long Kiss Goodnight' leaves a lot to be desired. As the director and his team have not done enough research on Amnesia, Geena Davis as a fearless butt kicking spy is more convincing than a poor Amnesia victim whose past career involved spying for US government. The film also appears to be more of a comedy film with actor Samuel.L.Jackson mouthing countless stupidities. His character has been reduced to that of a third rate stooge. By today's standards,this film's action scenes are OK. In a broader perspective,they are an important relic of a period when many action oriented films were made in Hollywood.

Review title: Loud, dumb and fun, though one could expect more from Shane Black
Review_body: The main problem with Renny Harlin is he can't find the right script to combine with his talent as an action director. Actually, he did once (Die Hard 2, 1990), but since then he has never succeeded in making a film that's equally good. He gets pretty close with The Long Kiss Goodnight, though, even if it must be said that this time he manages to do a better job than the writer, Shane Black (Lethal Weapon).If there's one thing that Black knows, it's how to pair two radically different people and get one hell of a story out of their chemistry. This time round, however, one of the two characters is less involving than the other, and it's a shame, considering it's the protagonist I'm talking about. Her name is Samantha Caine (Geena Davis), she's a teacher and leads a happy life alongside her boyfriend and daughter. Unfortunately, she doesn't remember anything about herself except the last eight years, and so she hires a P.I. (Samuel L. Jackson) to find out who she was. What he uncovers is not exactly pleasant: apparently, Sam's real name is Charly Baltimore, she used to work for the CIA as a professional assassin and there are a lot of people who believed her to be dead and want to correct that mistake.Even for modern action movie standards, the plot is a bit far-fetched, and it doesn't help that Davis never fully manages to make her transition from regular housewife to merciless killer convincing, leaving it to Jackson to seduce the audience. And seduce he does: Black may not be Tarantino, but his dialogue is a joy to hear nonetheless, and in the Pulp Fiction star's mouth it becomes priceless ("Were you always that stupid, or did you take lessons?" he gets asked at one point; his deadpan answer? "I took lessons"). The supporting cast is not bad either (especially Brian Cox, who plays similar roles in The Bourne Identity and X2 as well, and David Morse), but other than Jackson the film's selling point is the action scenes: loud, huge, incredibly violent, just what the audience needs to be distracted from the script's weaknesses - yes, it is definitely a Renny Harlin movie.Bottom line: average plotting, questionable logic, uneven characterization, cracking dialogue, great action. Worth a look? Yes, but do not expect anything special.

Review title: One of the most impressive and most underrated action movies of the 1990's.
Review_body: An woman in her mid-thirties by the name of Samantha Caine (Oscar-Winner:Geena Davis), who doesn't know her identity. Since she has amnesia and not knowing, who's the father of her child (Yvonne Zima). Samantha is now living normal life as a school teacher and living with a caring boyfriend (Tom Amandes). Then Samantha is slowly finding out about her past with pieces of her memories coming back now and then. But her mysterious former employers wants her dead. She finds herself pursued by hi-tech assassins from a corrupted government. Samantha is helped by a low rent, wise-cracking private detective (Samuel L. Jackson). Who's helping her to uncover her past before they turn up dead.Directed by Renny Harlin (A Nightmare on Elm Street 4:The Dream Master, Cliffhanger, Cutthroat Island) made an extremely entertaining action film that knows how to thrill the audiences. But unfortunately this movie was an box office disappointment, due of a bad release date. But like most films, it did find life on video. The plot might seems hokey and far fetched for some tastes but Shane Black (Kiss Kiss Bang Bang, Lethal Weapon, The Last Boy Scout) script does work well enough to overcome certain flaws. This has some of the most spectacular action sequences ever filmed. This has an terrific score by Alan Silvestri (Back to the Future Trilogy, Forrest Gump, Predator) and Dazzling Visual Effects. A must for action fans. Larry King plays himself in a cameo near the closing credits. Super 35. (****/*****).

Christmas Eve? The wrong place at the right time? Sound familiar? "The Long Kiss Goodnight" could quite easily have been a third sequel in the action series "Die Hard". Just substitute Bruce Willis for Geena Davis, put him in Niagara Falls where a group of 'black ops' are planning some terrorist activity and wammo, there you have it. And director Renny Harlin should be quite aware of the similarities.Having helmed the second in the trilogy, "Die Harder", and being the man who directed Stallone's career resurrecting "Cliff Hanger", Harlin seems to be just the man for the job of guiding wife Geena Davis and Samuel L. Jackson (probably the hottest property in Hollywood at the moment) through their paces in this new action extravaganza, "The Long K.G.". Though if you ask New Line Cinema they may tend to disagree, after all they have been in court trying desperately to get out of a multi-film contract with Harlin and Davis after their "Cuthroat Island" did a big bellyflop.Plot from Shane Black concerns a deadly femme (cross Sigourney Weaver's "Ripley" with Linda Hamilton's "Sarah Connor" and Anne Parillaud's "Nikita" and you might be close) whose severe amnesia has her believing she is a mild mannered school teacher from Pennsylvania, rather than a cold blooded assassin from the CIA. But when Charlene Elizabeth Baltimore finally remembers who she is............... well boom! You can guess the rest. In fact you really can guess the rest, as predictability sets in from here on. Hey, forget about that though, this flick ain't about storyline, its about action, and there's plenty of that to go around.Harlin's experience in action pics shows as he sets up some fine pieces for our viewing pleasure, while both Davis, Jackson and the support cast get some good lines. Otherwise the leads aren't asked to do too much, and considering their acting capabilities (Davis in "The Accidental Tourist" and Jackson "Pulp Fiction") this is well below their standard. Samuel L. in particular seems to be finding it hard to shake off the shadow of Jules Winfield, the philosophical hit-man from "Pulp Fiction", that is if his opening scene is anything to go by. Some may call it homage, but I don't know about that. Mr. Jackson probably doesn't mind too much either way.Special f/x are nothing short of top dollar, though editing may have been a tad under done. Cinematography is superb, hardly being able to miss with Niagara Falls as a target, while Harlin has used the end credits to throw in a sweeping, panoramic shot. Alan Silvestri provides the music.In short, one can easily look past the numerous plot holes and enjoy a romping good time with invincible heroes, and two dimensional, obvious villains with too much charm and not enough brains.Thursday, January 30, 1997 - Village Centre Melbourne

Consider that director Renny Harlin and wife Geena Davis made 'Cutthroat Island' only one year earlier and you almost have to call this movie good. Review title: The last time I got blown, candy bars cost a nickel.
Review_body: Geena Davis and Samuel L Jackson were on fire in this film. The premise was totally unbelievable: a small-town school teacher one minute and the next coolly declaring to an enemy ''You're gonna die screaming. I'm gonna watch.'' That was the story. Seven years of amnesia and now she is back to finish her job. There is more action in this film than in in any Bruce Willis action flick. Director Renny Harlin, who also directed Die Hard 2: Die Harder, learned and outdid himself. Jackson and Davis really meshed as co-stars and made the film that much more enjoyable. If you like you action fast and hot, then this is a not-to-be-missed adventure.

Not a box office success; no-one really knows why.  It may have failed simply because of its title.  It looks as though you need a two-word tough-guy title to attract a sufficient proportion of the idiot crowd - "Die Hard", "Lethal Weapon", "Hard Weapon", "Die Lethal", etc. - talking about "the long kiss goodnight" will get you nowhere.  But for once Renny Harlin has made a GOOD action movie.  A large part of the reason for this lies in the fact that the central character, Samantha, earns our affection and interest early on.  As she becomes Charly again, we're torn: we certainly want Charly to thwart the bad guys, and all that; but we don't want her to lose touch with Samantha in order to do so - even though we like Charly, too.  Geena Davis bestows all of her considerable charm on both halves of the central character.  Samuel L. Jackson plays second fiddle for a change. It turns out he's good at it.  That was a compliment.Intelligent, far superior to anything in the "Die Hard" series - if I were more cynical I'd add, "it's not surprising that it didn't do well", but I don't really feel that way; it IS surprising that it didn't do well.

The great thing about Shane Black (of "Lethal Weapon" fame) is that he makes action movies work by doing things that look really obvious on the surface. It makes sense that you have the audience care for the characters before you put them in mortal danger, but how many action movies actually bother to do that? You don't even need a long build-up or anything. There are just these quick moments here, subtle touches, some funny lines that make us like Geena Davis' character right from the start. Once you realise her wholesome family life is nothing more than a cover for a professional killer, you genuinely feel bad, even though you've only seen a couple of scenes. That's great writing. Geena Davis is kind of an unlikely action star, but she does fine and Samuel L. Jackson (who can take more abuse than RoboCop in this movie) is a great comic relief. "The Last Kiss Goodnight" was a complete dud at the box office, but thankfully it's gained a cult following once it hit the video shelves.

If it wasn't for the humor and Samuel L. Jackson playing in it, I would probably never have finished this movie. I don't mind watching an action movie, but I do want at least a bit of realism and if there is something this movie completely lacked, it must be realism. Big guns and explosions, car chases, a few thousand bad guys and only one good woman to stop them, YES. Realistic, not really.At first this movie seems completely normal. You see a caring housewife, happy with her work, kid and boyfriend. Her only problem is that she suffers from amnesia. But than it all goes completely over the top. The housewife appears to be a secret agent / government assassin. As she tries to recover the missing parts of her past, she is chased by her ex-employers, who want her dead.If it wasn't for Samuel L. Jackson in it, this movie would probably have gone by completely unnoticed, but I have to admit that the man is a real pro. Even though it probably isn't his best performance ever, you will not be disappointed by it. The other actors are OK, but certainly not as good as Jackson. All in all this is a movie I'll soon be forgotten. Therefor I give it a 5,5/10. I expected a lot more.

Samantha Caine (Geena Davis) is a school teacher who suffers from amnesia, she hires Mitch Henessey (Samuel L. Jackson) a dead-beat private detective, and together they set out to discover her past, before it comes back and kills her. She discovers that she is in fact Charlie Baltimore, a highly trained secret agent and killer; and so begins a great thrill ride.Geena Davis plays the tough all action star convincingly, bringing a fresh take on the action genre. Samuel L. Jackson is the bumbling sidekick, and he is fantastic in the role, taking a break from the cool character we're used to seeing.This movie somehow failed to impress at the box office, and i cannot imagine why; it has all the right ingredients. The direction is solid, the script is both funny and interesting, the characters are believable, the acting is first class, the action is plentiful and really exciting - need i say more? 8/10

Several schoolboy errors e.g. failing to consult Film Editing for Dummies and assuming your audience to be the most gullible and naive idiots to have roamed the earth since the last ice age. Action thrillers are designed to provide their audiences with excitement, entertainment and escapism and "The Long Kiss Goodnight" certainly meets all of these criteria. A sequence during which the movie's two main protagonists race down a corridor followed by a rapidly accelerating fireball and escape by leaping out of a high-level window exemplifies this perfectly, as the stunt, which is obviously far-fetched, is extremely exciting to watch as well as being laugh-out-loud funny. The stunts, explosions and chases in this film are all brilliantly staged and together with its very witty script and lively pace, contribute to an end product that's really enjoyable.Samantha Caine (Geena Davis) is a schoolteacher in a small town in Pennsylvania who enjoys a very pleasant lifestyle with her good natured fiancé and her young daughter. Her only real problem is that she can't remember anything about her life before the occasion eight years earlier when she was found on a New Jersey beach suffering from amnesia. Things start to change however, after she's involved in a car crash and a blow to the head triggers some disturbing flashbacks and she suddenly displays a level of dexterity with a knife that leads her to believe that, in her previous life, she must've been a chef!! Mitch Henessey (Samuel L Jackson), a private detective that Samantha had hired to check out her past, arrives at her house with some information just after she's been involved in a fight with a one-eyed convict who'd escaped from prison after seeing TV coverage of her taking part in her town's Christmas parade. This violent man obviously held her responsible for the loss of his eye and was out for revenge but the extraordinary combat skills that Samantha uses in subduing him shock both her and her fiancé.Mitch's information leads to the discovery that, in her past, Samantha had been a government assassin called Charly Baltimore who'd succeeded in preventing some corrupt CIA personnel from detonating a bomb at Niagara Falls and blaming the atrocity on terrorists in order to elicit more funding from Congress. Unfortunately, Mitch and Samantha / Charly also learn that a new group is planning to carry out a similar attack and that, as they're seen as a threat to that group, their lives are in immediate danger. Their only option is to go on the run and this leads them into further violent encounters when amongst other things, Charly gets tortured, her daughter gets kidnapped and Mitch gets seriously injured.Geena Davis and Samuel L Jackson work well individually and together in this movie. They make a great team as she excels in her role as an action heroine and he provides a whole series of marvellous one-liners. The humour that runs through the movie is also pivotal to its success because it makes the most unbelievable action sequences seem totally acceptable and induces its audience to cheerfully overlook inconvenient details such as how someone with no background and a made up name could've had the necessary formal qualifications to get a job as a schoolteacher. Similarly, the potentially negative impact of the film's high body count, strong violence and swearing is also successfully mitigated and made more acceptable because of its clever use of comedy.

Review title: Renny Harlin and Shane Black make and enjoyable action flick
Review_body: Certainly a vast improvement over the legendary debacle of Cutthroat Island , the previous collaboration of the then husband-and-wife team of director Renny Harlin and star Geena Davis, this overblown action thriller starts out very strong but fails to pay off in a satisfying conclusion. Acting really isn't the hallmark of the action genre, so suffice it to say that the cast is what is required of a fast-paced pulp tale littered with corpses and explosions: They grunt, grimace, and grit their teeth with appropriate determination when firing a weapon or jumping from great heights. It's the script by Shane Black that makes or breaks a film such as this, so it's a pleasant surprise that The Long Kiss Goodnight  starts off with an inventive high-concept twist, developing a character nicely. Sadly, it then morphs somewhere in the second act into a routine series of percussive beats and a predictable government espionage/conspiracy/paranoia tale. If their project had delved into the issues of identity as thoughtfully as those action epics based on the works of novelist Philip K. Dick, the filmmakers might truly have had something not only viscerally exciting but intellectually fresh and stimulating on their hands. My final thoughts on the movie are The Long Kiss Goodnight was one of the better action films released in 96. Shane Black who been away from the buddy genre came back hard with this action film that features the sexy Genna Davis as an ex-spy. Samuel L.Jackson provides great comic releif though I didn't like the way he was beat up in the movie. If you want action and comedy with a female hero this is the movie for you.

Review title: In New York I'm Frank, in Chicago I'm Earnest,, lol
Review_body:
Samantha has no memory of her life before 8 yrs ago. She was found with no memory, and 2 months pregnant with her daughter. She leads a quiet life as a teacher in a small town, with her daughter and long time boyfriend. One night she hits a deer and gets thrown out of her car. The trauma of the accident jolts some of her memories to come back,, and
she stumbles over to the injured deer, who is crying in pain. She grabs its horns and expertly breaks its neck,, no remorse shown. So,,, who was she before?I remember this one didn't do near as well at the box office as they predicted it would,, and while I can actually see how that was the case,, it's still a fun movie if you want to watch a movie. It's got plenty of Jackson being Jackson, so you'll be plenty entertained.

There is a serious scene in this movie. A scene that lets you know that his film won't be pulling many cheap punches. It takes place in a crowded train station and the protagonists are ambushed by assassins with automatic weapons. They make a break for it and just manage to get out in a hail of gunfire. The main hall of the train station is now filled with corpses of innocent people that were caught in the crossfire. Some would call that too sad and/or grim to put into what is supposed to be an enjoyable action flick. I call it honesty. Most action movies tend to lean toward the "safe side" of showing violence and plot elements. This mostly means that in spite massive shootouts innocent people tend not to die or at least we don't see them die. The violence is all purely the good guys versus the bad guys with mainly the bad guys dying. A bit of common sense clearly shows this to be absurd.Renny Harlin showed a hint of this in his first (and sadly only) hit, Die Hard 2. The villains intentionally crash a plane full of people to get their point across. The scene was also filmed with a backup scene of a cargo plane with only a few people on-board going down, but the grimmer and probably more realistic scenario ended up being used. However, to fit the spirit of the first film, Die Hard 2 was mostly a "fun action movie." Here, that grimmer and more convincing edge is pervasive. The violence is bloody. The one liners are hilarious, but with a certain style that more echoes natural human sarcasm than clichéd film wisecracks at key moments of action. The plot is also packed with more malicious intent than most action films. The villain is not just some rogue out for revenge or a mad grab at power. It is less ridiculous, but also more frightening than that. From recent films, the "Bourne" trilogy almost gets there with its less cheesy than usual action film style, but this film is from 1996 and 7 years before "The Bourne Identity" with Matt Damon made it to the big screen.Another interesting aspect is that the main hero is actually a heroine. And this is well before the movie version of "Tomb Raider" became a hit. What's more is that this heroine genuinely looks like she could take down John McClane and then take his still lit cigarette. This movie marks Geena Davis's second action-heroine role and she still didn't manage to score a hit. While Angelina Jolie stars in "Tomb Raider" years later and scores a hit. The reasons are beyond me. Completely.Lastly, this movie isn't all dark edged. There are many outrageous and spectacular set pieces that one can only see in an action film. The climatic explosion of a chemical bomb is an absolutely spectacular display of movie pyrotechnics, with more than one law of physics taking a convenient break. Thus, there is formula here, but it is the Anti-Formula for the everyday Hollywood Action Movie Formula. --- 9/10BsCDb Classification: 13+ --- violence, profanity

Review title: Cheesy and dumb , but fun popcorn action movie
Review_body: *SPOILERS*SPOILERS*SPOILERS*SPOILERS*SPOILERSThe tile is a reference to the fact that Samantha kissed her other personality goodbye. She stopped searching about her past – that's it. It was probably inspired by the movie "The long goodbye" by Robert Altman – Samuel L. Jackson is watching this movie in the hotel.The movie is very stupid at some places . How did the one-eyed prisoner escaped from the prison ? Plot hole. Why didn't he broke into Samantha's house or kill her with a sniper gun from the distance , while she was for example shopping ? The motivation for the main villains to do the bad things is ABSURD. Little girl hides in the worst place possible.The movie is also very cheesy and unrealistic sometimes . Samantha seems immune to pain , cold and has TOO MUCH STRENGTH. The assassination by the one-eyed guy is ridiculous , same as the flashbacks with Charlie. Oh , and the little girl is annoying.Thankfully there are some good things here. Geena Davis gives a good performance and is very convincing with both of her personalities. Samuel L. Jackson is fun as always and David Morse is solid as always. Renny Harlin always makes sure that his movies aren't boring and this is no exception. I guess he really put some effort to make this movie entertaining with his wife (Davis) as the main star. Shane Black , the writer of "Lethal weapon" provides us some incredibly funny moments and dialogues . Thanks to the humor watching this movie is rather painless. The scene "What I told you about smoking ?" is one of the funniest I've seen.It's not a good movie , but it's too good to be "so bad , it's good " type of movie. This is no "Bourne identity". It's cheesy and stupid , but thankfully there is a good ironic distance to the whole story . It doesn't take itself too seriously and if you lower your expectations you should have one night of mindless fun. It's certainly a better action movie with woman in main role than "Tomb raider". I give it 6/10.

Review title: A woman spy who suffered amnesia and is running away from her old chums.
Review_body: It seems that Geena Davis likes starring in action films, she is perhaps the female version of Arnold Schwarzenegger or Bruce Willis. The plot of the film is not new, with several violent scenes, where Geena resists anything bad was coming over her. Samuel L. Jackson played a modest role in the film. The best of the film is the special effects, but the rest is available in other action films.

Review title: Last Kiss from action heroine Geena
Review_body: This starts out innocently enough: a pastoral setting in a small snow-covered town on Christmas, where Davis lives as a schoolteacher with a daughter. One hitch: she remembers nothing from before 8 years ago. One dark night on a drive on a slippery road, she hits a deer and then a tree (damn snow!). Things start coming back to her; at first, she thinks she was a chef, because she's real good with a knife. Then some bald psycho with a shotgun bursts into her home and she's forced to kill him. With a private eye (Jackson), she hits the road on a quest for her past: turns out, she was a CIA assassin. Soon she's chain-smoking, swearing, behaving lewdly, and dyeing her hair blond. Almost all scenes are in snow and one spectacular shot has them falling thru ice. Several persons die along the way. This entire description may seem to denote a vapid film, though it's definitely a stylish action thriller. But do we really care, at about the midway point, whether Geena will stay with her daughter and return to her quiet life? The answer is it's really difficult to care. Even in the early scenes, you sense this is not the life for Geena; she should be out there slashing throats. We care about who she'll kill next or who will next try to kill her - that's about it. There's an emptiness to the entire proceedings. Also, why would Jackson, as an everyman detective, involve himself with this obvious insanity? As with the early scenes, we move into dark comedy territory there, but it doesn't come across that way, being a straightforward thriller. Also, it's not said much, but this is all derivative of Robert Ludlum's "The Bourne Identity" with a female anti-hero rather than a male. NOTE: this was Geena's last shot at an action-star career, courtesy of her then-hubby, Director Renny Harlin, but this flic tanked at the box-office, which is why Geena then appeared in movies like "Stuart Little"(99).

Review title: Explosions, Blood, and They Blew Up The Rainbow Bridge
Review_body: Wow, a modern film showing my hometown, Niagara Falls, NY. Hey man, they blew up the Rainbow Bridge to Canada! We'll have to use the lower arch bridge now. Lots of explosions and lots of blood. Samuel L. Jackson is actually funny. Part are believable; and parts are not. Parts are brilliant, and parts are not. A fair big-budget action flick. Seen on Tubi, the free streaming website. It is nice to find a real theater movie on Tubi, even if it is 25 years old. Because most of their movies are awful.

Review title: With the fast-moving and ultraviolent The Long Kiss Goodnight, Geena Davis and director Renny Harlin have rebounded neatly from that disastrous pirate movie that quickly sank the previous year.
Review_body: Harlin can't restrain himself, however, and lets this one go needlessly overboard with a climax that uses more explosives than the entire Korean War. Davis is immensely appealing as a kick-butt heroine who gets to do extreme physical things usually reserved for Bruce, Arnold and Jean Claude. Harlin should have had more faith in Davis and refrained from the excessive pyrotechnics. She plays mild-mannered teacher and muffin-baking mom, Samantha Caine, who just happens to have a slight case of amnesia. Samantha can't remember anything of her previous life, not even the father of her eight-year-old daughter. Well, fasten your apron strings. A nasty conk on the head following an accidental run-in with Bambi starts to stir up a mess of repressed things in Samantha's brain. The model housewife turns out to be no Martha Stewart, but a gun-toting variation on La Femme Nakita named Charly Baltimore. The former hit woman teams up with a wisecracking private eye to solve the attendant riddles about her past and to fight for her survival in the future. Samuel L. Jackson seems to be thoroughly enjoying himself as the sidekick. He gets most of the funny lines from the often inventive screenplay of Shane Black. This Kiss may be somewhat sloppy, but it delivers a blow from across the room.

Review title: Some of The Best Stunts Ever!
Review_body: "The Long Kiss Goodnight" has gotten a bad rap since it was first released. Mostly because of the Geena Davis/Renny Harlin marriage/collaboration that created this and the much-maligned "Cutthroat Island," which was released the previous year. That was too bad, because "The Long Kiss Goodnight" is by far the best of the 2, and an incredible film.Davis plays Samantha Caine, a sweet school teacher who lives in a town in New England with her boyfriend (Tom Amandes) and daughter (Yvonne Zima). The only wrinkle in her perfect life is the fact that she has no inkling of her past life. She was found unconscious and pregnant 8 years before. Samantha's life at this point is as bland as low-fat cookies, until a car accident triggers memories and skills. Soon, someone shows up at her door, attempting to kill her. What could possibly be the reason for this? Seems that sweet-as-sugar Samantha is really deadly-as-cyanide Charley Baltimore, government assassin. With the help of Mitch (The excellent as always Samuel L. Jackson), Charlie begins to discover why particular persons want her dead, especially the mysterious Timothy (Craig Bierko).The film has some fantastic scenes. 4 of my favorites: 1) The shootout at the station. When Samantha and Mitch take a dive out a window, and she shoots through the ice so they can land in the water instead of splattering on the ice. Great! 2) When Samantha regains her memory. Samantha is tied to a waterwheel, stripped to her slip, and being dunked into freezing cold water. You see her change each time she is dunked, from helpless Samantha to killer Charly.3) The Rebirth of Charly: With the cool song "She's Not There" being used to good effect, Charly is going through a makeover, changing her hair, putting on the makeup, and putting the moves on a confused and bruised Mitch. And the thing she does with the shot glass? Cool! 4) The bomb at the border. The sheer magnitude of the explosion boggles the mind as you watch Mitch, Charly and her daughter trying to outrace it.This is one of Harlin's best films and it's gotten a bad rap. This film is worth looking at. If you ever decide to have a Harlin film fest (And somewhere, someone may.), then this should be on it.

Review title: Fun but very formulated silly movie
Review_body: Fun but really silly movie. The epitome of the action movies where every bad guy explains their plan to the hero before they attempt to kill them i.e. Leaves the hero every opportunity to kill them or escape.If you enjoy over-the-top bad dialogue, one-liners, unrealistic shoot-outs, and action, then you will love this.So is it mildly entertaining and worth watching? Sure. But don't expect much more than what I described. It's the standard derivative action film where the bad guys kidnap the hero's loved one, here it's her daughter, and then hold them hostage for some superfluous demands and give them a long speech before they attempt to "finish it off." This is literally every James Bond film ever made and literally the vast majority of action films.And if it's ever confusing to you or you don't know why anything is happening, don't worry, it will all be explained in exposition through a three-minute dialogue between the hero and villain.And of course, instead of just shooting someone right there even though they are captures, tied, and gagged, they leave them "to die" providing every opportunity to escape.It's the old "Mr, Bond, I will kill you now, but before, let me first tell you my plan to destroy the world" scenario.It's lazy writing, i.e. The plot is all TELL, no show, meaning it's all explained instead of shown. Also, the acting of her daughter was atrocious and they made sure every second of the musical score made you feel a certain way.In summary, this is Die Hard meets Bond meets Aliens all in one nicely formulated Hollywood package.Despite my criticism, it's a movie you can watch if you are bored to death, albeit a late-night cable movie.

I absolutely loved this film. Samuel Jackson's character and his portrayal of it was such a welcome surprise. Geena Davis was awesomely scary, reminding me of the strong female characters in Person of Interest.

Dumb over the top action movie. There's nothing believable about it. The acting is bad, the characters are bad, the script is bad. Maybe the idea was good but the end result is awful. It's not the worst I've seen but there are more entertaining action movies out there!

Another underrated action flick, this is one of the best of its type of the decade, and features some of Samuel's best lines. Geena's character suffers from amnesia, but her memory begins to return after her kind suburban home is attacked by gunmen, who want her dead. Helped, to a certain degree by Samuel's taxi driving, quick witted character, she goes in search of her past, and realises she must stop the bad guys etc. The plot is not original, but the dialogue and action more than makes up for that, and Davis proves she is a strong, varied, talented actress becoming cold blooded secret agent halfway through the movie, much to the surprise of Jackson. Her character is one of the strongest female action figures, not quite up there with Sarah Conner, or Ripley, but much more effective than Lara Croft, Charlie's Angels, or any other recent shams. She will protect her family at all costs, not letting any man stop her from living the life she has chosen, and although that sounds weak, my words do not do her justice. It's not entirely serious, but it is in my opinion better than all of Harlin's previous efforts, including Die Hard 2. 8 out of 10

This film is really fun. Davis has a tendency to be in really bad movies, but this one, I like. I love the transformation from ordinary wife-teacher to cool and horny agent chick. Great fun to watch Samuel L. Jackson gaping in disbelief at the same transition.There is not a moments relief, either. The action goes on and never stops until the very end. Great fun, and one of Harlin's few good movies.

Maybe 15. Thats all the time you can devote to this paint by numbers bombz before you are out of there. It boasts a computer generated script, with a lot of explosions. I wonder if this could have possibly made any money. These things look so expensive to make and they are terrible, so they cannot possibly give any sort of ROI. If as I suspect, they cleverly use stock footage from other films for the action sequences, then it all makes sense. Geena Davis? puleeze. Jackson is ok, I like him. Maybe he or his agent will learn how to read a script one of these days. I think Showtime needs to show it more than the 40 times per week it is currently scheduled. I want to see if my television will actually melt.

Review title: High octane, bug budget action thriller. Very entertaining nonetheless.
Review_body:
"The Long Kiss Goodnight" is an enjoyable and very cool action thriller, and a career breakthrough for Geena Davis. The plot is very familiar to that of The Bourne Identity but so what. The fight scenes are a real treat for the eyes and the plotline is strong enough to keep you engaged for the 2 hours.
It's directed with a slick sense of style and avoids most action cliches. Geena Davis is great as an action chick and gets past her usual "good wife" role. Samuel L. Jackson is good as usual as the supporting player. The film's baddie is overly cheesy though and you can tell what's going to happen to him. It breaks away from the usual run-of-the-mill actioners such as Commando and On Deadly Ground and is definetly one of the best actioners in years. Good fun and good popcorn entertainment. 7.4/10.

It's off-the-wall entertainment - I mean how director Renny Harlin has made his action movies and "The Long Kiss Goodnight" isn't completely similar to his past work ("Die Hard 2", "Cliffhanger").The story follows Geena Davis as Samantha Catlin, a sweet-hearted schoolteacher who suffers from amnesia, and raises a daughter with her boyfriend.  Catlin's past manages to catch up with her as she finds out from her current private investigator, Mitch (Samuel L. Jackson) that she used to be a top-notch C.I.A. assassin.  It isn't too long before the feds, led by Timothy (Craig Bierko) quickly make their presence and try to kill Catlin.Some of the characters that the tandem come upon for information like Dr. Nathan Waldman (Brian Cox) and Luke (David Morse) turn into very bland life-and-death situations.I felt irritated and helpless in finding out why Samantha and Mitch are being sought after.  The film's script, written by Shane Black ("Lethal Weapon"), provides the necessary thrills and humor yet it deserves a much better plot and lacks any real suspense.  Jackson himself provides most of the humor and the one line about people who fail in trying to get out of New Jersey is hilarious.

I don't see how even action fans could appreciate this.  Somebody really messed up on the screenplay here, and it's utterly unbelievable that the director of "Die Hard 2" would waste his time with this.  Terrible screenplay and dumb jokes combine to completely ruin this movie. 2/10.

I rented this on DVD one night mainly because i liked the actors and i knew the director, i didn't really know what it was about. Many people call this an excellent film, while many others say it's terrible. Although i enjoyed this movie, I can understand the people who dislike it. This movie changes from being an excellent mystery thriller to an excellent action thriller. That change could have been a bit too radical for some. There are many people who hate over-the-top action films like this one, and when they realise, during the film, that this isn't an intense psychological thriller, but another action movie, they will be disappointed. They realise that this isn't the movie they expected from the scene when the guy in the prison starts swearing in anger seeing that Charly is still alive. But even those who like action with an interesting plot, will be disappointed with the ending. It's way too long, the disasters even become boring after a while, and the final explosion looks like the apocalypse in Terminator 2.
Despite some inevitable flaws, this movie is guaranteed to entertain those who like action. And for those who like complicated and deep plots: give it a try, your opinion on action films might change.

Review title: Proof That Renny Harlin is Great and Everyone Else is Wrong
Review_body: Renny Harlin is a great director, the haters can suck it. He proved himself with Die Hard 2, proved himself again with Cliffhanger, and did a hat trick of awesomeness with The Long Kiss Goodnight. The man is responsible for three of the best action movies out there, let him live.Geena Davis and Samuel L. Jackson are perfect for their roles. I'm not a fan of Davis and she didn't wow me, but she did a good job and she looked good in the action scenes. Samuel L. Jackson, one of my favorite actors, is for me the best thing about the movie. He delivers his lines so well and is the height of cool. He too looks good during the action scenes, and his performance is extremely likable. Then again, he is a veteran actor, so it was expected.Shane Black, arguably the greats scriptwriter out there, hits a home run once again with this masterpiece. The dude knows how to write. With crackling dialogue and awesome action scenes, this script is definitely top-notch.The high point is, obviously, the action, and this film doesn't disappoint. The house fight, the train station shootout, the car chase, the base shootout, and the final battle on the bridge are all wildly entertaining. The bridge explosion near the end is probably one of the best explosions I've ever seen in a movie.If you're looking for a stupidly entertaining action movie, there are few better places to turn to than this film.

I love these main actors in most of what they've done, but I actually got bored watching them. It started as interesting, then the story swung to government secret operatives, that was the first yawn. Then the road trip, SLJ making a jerks play on GD is silly, but the easy call to meet up with BC, it's sloppy screenwriting. It's all been done far better before.

Review title: Silly and confusing and built on false premise
Review_body: Geena Davis plays a former govt assassin who now has amnesia and lives as an ordinary single mom. Now right there you have problems since such a phenomenon is a Hollywood fiction. People do not lose their identity of self unless their brain is so damaged they can't do anything. Anyway, govt agents who thought she was dead find out she's alive and want to kill her. Slowly her memory comes back and she turns into superwoman and the action begins.And there is plenty of action but so much of the story is just preposterous. I could mention a million holes in this film but you get the idea. Best thing in the movie is geena. I've always thought she had a quirky kind of good lucks but midway thru the film she cuts her hair and dies it blonde and looks gorgeous.Interesting detail in the movie is that the govt mentions that the the 1993 terror attack on the WTC was engineered by the CIA. This movie was made in 1996, five years before 9-11 but everybody with a brain knows that was an inside job too.

Review title: A good thriller with a sense of humor.
Review_body: Almost no cinema experience can beat a good thriller with a sense of humor. Geena Davis is a schoolteacher housewife who suffers from amnesia.  She'e even on the PTA!  But then an auto accident awakens the woman she used to be, and it's HOT!  Samuel L. Jackson is hilarious as the low rent private eye who tries to help Davis find her past, only to find out he's in way over his head.  Davis has some hilarious lines too, and the interaction between her and Jackson works surprisingly well.Look for Brian Cox, the original Hannibal Lechter, and David Moorse finally managing to shed his St. Elsewhere TV image.  The film is directed by Davis' husband, who almost seems to have built the whole film around her, but it works.I pull out this DVD and rewatch it often.  I still love the makeup scene. Is Geena hot or what?

Review title: Hey, I didn't go in expecting Hamlet
Review_body: This movie is exactly what it's supposed to be. It's a fun, over the top, action flick. We get the bonus that the heroic bad ass is a woman and she's in the PTA. To me there is one line that makes the entire movie. "Oh no honey, you're not going to die, they are."

Review title: Two Thirds of a Good Movie
Review_body: "The Long Kiss Goodnight" plays like "True Lies" meets "Total Recall". No bad thing and mostly well-handled, but what lets it down is the third act.After a lot of action, blood, swearing and zippy one-liners the film bogs down in a predictable finale mire, involving one of the most inert screen moppets of modern times. Yvonne Zima was about 7 at the time of this film and could not act. Having the story revolve around a kid with all the screen presence of workbench was A Bad Thing. Why did a child have a central role in this movie anyway? It's chock-full of people doing bad things and swearing fit to make a trooper blush. This is no family-orientated action blockbuster. Apart from little Yvonne's lack of acting skill, I also found myself stepping back and wondering what she was doing in this blood-splattered swearfest anyway. Especially, it has to be said, when you find out who the kid's father is. This unconvincing revelation leads on to one of the lamest action movie moments EVER. Shame on all concerned for committing it to celluloid.Shane Black and Renny Harlin deserve The Big Stick for this one, folks. The screenwriter and director literally lost the plot at the end of this film. Both are experienced and successful action veterans but neither of them did anything to sort out the woefully preposterous and clichéd third act of TLKG. Another crew member who needs a slap is Tricia Sawyer, who was Geena Davis's makeup "artist". Davis's transition from Suzie Homemaker to Spy Bitch is a pretty startling one for all the wrong reasons. The PEROXIDE SKULL PANDA OF DEATH look is never an easy one to pull off.

Excellent casting with Bierko (The Thirteenth Floor) as the arch bad guy, Jackson and Davis at their best, with Brian Cox and David Morse adding even more credibility to the story line. Cox delivers some abolutely hilarious lines with a straight face as only he can. No holds barred violence in this fantasy action thriller all the way through to the exhilarating end.
Very close to the definition of absolute action thriller

A Long Kiss Goodnight is another action vehicle with a promising start that eventually falls apart. The action scenes run the gamut from cool to the point of ridiculousness and the bad guy nemesis played by Craig Bieko is a throwaway. Maybe if the filmmakers had held some restrain on the over-the-top action scenes this could have been more of a dark atmospheric action flick instead of what it is: a loud stupid action picture ever so common today. Fun, but forgettable.Real memorable movies are all about the right elements coming together and clicking. The Long Kiss Goodnight has some of the right elements to make a good action movie. It has both a capable director in Renny Harlin (Die Hard 2) and a capable action writer in Shane Black (who's writing credits include Lethal Weapon) and we have Samuel L. Jackson, the master of movie coolness to boot. Unfortunately Harlin is never able to inject any juice into the material, this is hardly Black's best writing and Jackson can only do so much. An action movie doesn't have to be realistic and believable, but it must be entertaining. The Long Kiss Goodnight is entertaining to a degree, but it can go from sharp to stupid very quickly. Not helping matters any is the minimal character development given in particular to the bad guys and of course the formula of having the "good guys" get repeatedly captured yet we know they'll escape.I applaud Geena Davis though for taking a risk on such a different project. I could stand to see her again in another and hopefully better action vehicle. Sweet sassy-molassy! She looks pretty fine. As for Samuel L. Jackson, at times he seemed like the only reason to continue watching. Some of his scenes are quite comical especially one with Ronny Cox that's just great. These bits help break up the downward slope this movie gradually takes. Final result is if you like gonzo action and don't mind a predictable plot on autopilot, you'll like this. Of course, if you're like minded, you expect slightly more than run of the mill action movie extravaganzas nowadays.

Review title: One deer running across the road in the middle of the night
Review_body: Lots of action, shoot em up. Great plot. One deer running across the road in the middle of the night changed the future.

Review title: Would have been great but for all the explosions and stuff
Review_body: A school teacher mother, Samantha Caine (Geena Davis), who can't remember anything about her life before 8 years ago, has all that time had private detectives trying to learn about her past. Apparently to save money, she has gone from top rung PIs to less classy ones. We meet the current one, Mitch (Samuel L. Jackson), while he is pulling a sleazy scam shakedown of a "John" lured in by his partner, Trin (Melina Kanakaredes). Coincidentally, a suitcase with info about Samantha's past comes into Trin's possession just when a close up of Samantha is viewed by a prisoner watching a Xmas parade and he can't believe "Charlie" is alive. Charlie is Samantha's real name, and we eventually realize she has a completely different personality than Samantha. Charlie is a highly skilled assassin/spy for a secret U.S. gov't agency.The film is at its humorous best when Samantha begins to recall and perform some of Charlie's skills. Geena Davis is wonderful and fun to watch in just about every film or TV show she's in.What detracted from a good story was the ridiculous action scenes. In several they are being shot at by many bad guys with machine guns but don't get hit as they run through the barrage. In another scene Charlie is being tortured, forced under water for 5 minutes at a time, but repeatedly manages to hold her breath and isn't even gagging when she is allowed up. Despite that, the supposedly clever enemy mastermind keeps repeating this torture. Expecting a different result from repeating the same thing is a sign of what? Certainly not intelligence.Similarly, although they know that Charlie is extremely resourceful and dangerous, instead of just killing her out right they elect to kill her slowly and out of their sight. At times our heroes are totally incapacitated by obviously serious wounds, but then they recover, or are resurrected, with enough strength to do physical battle. At least their injuries don't magically disappear.If the special effects were included to appeal to a wider audience, it apparently didn't have the desired effect. Still, Long Kiss Goodnight deserves more than the 2 out of 4 stars my cable's guide rated it.

Reviewing Mindhunters on these boards I stated that Long Kiss Goodnight was the only Renny Harlin's masterpiece, only to emphasize how Mindhunters isn't. Now, after probably the tenth time I've seen this Long-Titled Movie I can stand by that statement with sincerity. Just like Die Hard series this piece of film-making manages to stay fresh and much more pleasurable to watch than many newer action flicks.I can't really pinpoint why is this so but I can take a guess. For, when you start analyzing, you find many things in it that are really out there and not in a good way. The plot is complex and illogical, the dialog is convoluted at times (in order to explain things to audience), even the witty one-liners often seem forced, and generally the movie tries to be too smart for its own good, thus departing from pretty straightforward and laid-back Die Hard scheme it obviously relies upon.Having said that, this is still one of the best rides ever filmed. Kind of like a story of a superhero, but with plausible powers. An ordinary housewife, the proverbial Hockey Mom, discovers she is a vicious assassin, with an important mission at that. A set of events trigger her former forgotten self and she begins a journey to discover who she is, accompanied by questionably tough and faithful detective sidekick. Her transformation and the way her family and the detective witness it never runs old and that's why I'm watching this movie even today. Add a gripping pace and a couple of outlandish but remarkably made action scenes and there it is. A constant reminder how not long ago the movies were made to be thrilling.

Review title: kisses - long ones for this flick.
Review_body: Put your brain at rest, forget about intellectual analysis - just sit back and enjoy the hell out of this outrageously exciting, funny movie.First of all - its stars. Geena Davis and Samuel L. Jackson are outstanding whether they are blowing up anything nearby or tossing some really funny one liners back and forth.As for the action, it is almost never-ending. Lots of shootouts, lots of flame and fire, lots of car/people chasing, and lots of the infamous 'f' word, used as often as the 'the' word. Well, what the 'f', it's in Webster's Dictionary and, for that matter, so is the maternal version.Anyway, I highly recommend adding this one to your library. Unless you're a marshmallow you'll want to see it again - and again - and again.Curious. One of the songs in this movie was by Jars of Clay, a very well known Christian vocal group. Review title: Nostalgic, badass and brainless action film!
Review_body: Plot:Samantha Caine lives in a small town with her daughter. Eight years ago she emerged, two months pregnant, from a nearby river with no memory of her past or who she is. However, she's getting closer to finding out about her past.Analysis:The Long Kiss Goodnight is a classic 90s action movie with a familliar tone and format. The pattern of this era was over the top, funny action films that embraced the cheesiness and were an entertaining company to relax. With very basic plot, no fancy plans or clever villains and motives, these movies were all about beating people up, killing and blowing up stuff, a fun non-sense to stop thinking for a while.Despite that the plot of this movie makes more sense than other ones of this era, it's still a little bit too ridiculous to take it seriously. A woman that doesn't remember who she was before an accident that finds out more about herself with the cheesiest possible way, a villain too evil for no reason, a sidekick for no reason and a journey that you have to shut down your brain to be okay and enjoy the action.It's one of those films that have a very nostalgic essence, a specific style that feels really warm that you can't help but enjoy them at least a little bit. You can't really say they are bad or average, you just watch them and have fun without the abillity to understand why this is happenning. The Long Kiss Goodnight does exactly that, it feels right where it really shouldn't and despite a predictable, unreasonable plot it remains a beloved classic.The greatest thing about this movie is the badass action scenes. These days, exposions and gunfights are a major factor that defines the success of an action film with more difficult stunts, choreographies and cgi. This approach of modern cinema despite making the visuals aesthetically pleasing, also makes them much less impactful. The practical effects, the clumsy combat, the violent, dirty gunfights, everything feels so real and satisfying that redefines the meaning of the word "cool", it's the movie equivalent of junk food but it surely is very tasty.The dynamic duo of Geena Davis and Samuel L. Jackson steals the show with amazing chemistry, badass performances and cheesy lines, it's a very good cast and that gave this movie the key element to be entertaining. The major problem is on the plot, it's not enough to make this film look bad, but you have to do many compromises so you can enjoy it. It's the constant feeling of someone telling you "Deal with it" that's unpleasant and that's why I can't be always fully invested in the brainless action I was going for.Conclision:It's not one of the best action movies, not even one of the best cheesy brainless action movies, but it's quite enjoyable and you will have fun for sure watching this. Satisfaction depends on the expectations, if you can deal with everything that they have to do so this film can work, then don't think twice, it's for you. On the other hand, if you can't shut your brain down for this, it will be an okay typical 2-hour experience for you.Rating: 7.5/10

Review title: What the hell was so wrong about this movie!?
Review_body: I was happy to find out that at least now this movie is beginning to get the appreciation it deserves (just view those votes). Not top-class action like "Die Hard" or "Lethal Weapon", but still something like a solid 7 out of 10: fine script, good actors with working chemistry, and a director who knows what he wants (sadly, this was director Harlin's last good film. "Deep Blue Sea" managed to reach 'an OK rollercoaster-ride'- status, but "Cutthroat Island, and especially, "Driven" are well-deserved flops!) Personally I think the turn-off at the box-office might have been the "Woman as an action star"-theme. Well, give her a chance, because Davis does deliver a performance above par. And, after all, this film doesn't concentrate so much on the "feminine"-side, but instead on good ol' action, buddyism (Jackson as a sidekick is given a lot of room in here, plus his share of action- and about a thousand killer wisecracks!) and on the plot (from Shane Black, the writer of "Lethal Weapon" and "The Last Boy Scout". The latter of which as a movie is on very many levels much like this one...the theme, the clever plot, also as good and as underrated!) Overall: if one hasn't seen this one yet, don't forget to rent it for the next quiet Saturday night!

SPOILERS IN THIS REVIEWThe Long Kiss Goodnight is yet another prime example of a common affliction of many modern films; it starts off on a very interesting concept - a trained assassin whose memory was erased regains consciousness of herself - and the initial setup is engaging but then it seems the writers don't know very well where to go next and the whole thing trails off down increasingly confusing and/or inane paths, leaving the disappointing taste of something that was OK but promised to be a lot better. The baddies are remarkably unremarkable, and even Jackson's comic sidekick turn seems more like something from his pre-Pulp Fiction days; it looks like Harlin, as in Cutthroat Island, made every effort so that no-one would upstage his then wife. Her character is by far the best of the film and this fact only makes you feel even more frustrated that they weren't able to do something better with it.However, there is still something about this film which for me sets it apart from the run-of-the-mill hollywood actioner and places it above average, if only just. It is something very subtle I can't quite put my finger on; it's a disturbing, cold, dark, even sickly edge, a nightmarish and unreal feel, a decadent air, a mean streak, which keeps cropping up in various ways. It's in the dark reddish photography and almost permanent night the characters dwell in, it's in Samantha's dreams in front of the mirror, it's in her vicious eyes and smile whenever she's about to kill a man or when she announces how she will enjoy watching her nemesis die with her daughter listening, it's in Mitch's comeback at the wheel of a car while he is spurting so much blood from his mouth he can hardly speak... I don't know, it's an atmosphere, something I can't define but which gives me the creeps (a bit) and which makes this film still oddly intriguing for me.

Review title: truly elegant "goodbye" from a Hollywood a-lister

Review title: The Bourne Identity with a Feminine Twist
Review_body: I was interested in seeing 'The Long Kiss Goodnight' largely because the premise of the movie, an amnesiac CIA assassin on the run from his/her handlers, was similar to that of one of my favourite movies, Matt Damon starrer 'The Bourne Identity' and also because I had seen the recently released movie 'Salt' which is also about a lethal woman who's not all she seems. The movie follows Samantha Caine (Geena Davis) a schoolteacher suffering from amnesia who does not remember anything about her life before waking up on a beach in New Jersey eight years ago...not even the true father of her daughter Caitlin, with whom she was pregnant with at the time. Nevertheless, Samantha has buried the past and has all but 'kissed' her former self 'good night' when the trauma of a car crash causes her to suffer from illusions of a darker version of herself and she begins to rediscover lethal fighting skills she could never have believed she had. With the help of a seedy private detective Mitch Hennesey (Samuel L Jackson) she discovers that she is, or rather was, Charlene 'Charly' Baltimore, an assassin working for the CIA who went missing years ago after failing to execute her target. And when her old enemies catch up with her and attempt to torture her to death, all her memories and her old personality come flooding back, and our gentle and warm protagonist is transformed back into Charly, the cold blooded lethal femme fatale who has no compunctions about killing anyone who gets in her way, and who shuns the 'mundane' life of Samantha Caine. Charly embarks on a mission to uncover a conspiracy by her former handlers and her old nemesis and target Timothy to 'fake' a terrorist attack in order to convince the President of the US to increase the CIA's budget (a nefarious scheme which will nevertheless result in the very real deaths of hundreds of innocents). With the clock ticking towards disaster, and hit men chasing her, will Charly succeed in saving the day? And will she ever accept the life of Samantha Caine again?My feelings about this film are kind of mixed. This film clearly stands out from most other amnesia stories in that that most amnesia stories are about the protagonists trying to uncover their forgotten pasts, whereas here, the protagonist discovers her past pretty early on and has to instead deal with the ramifications of this discovery. However I did find the treatment of the Samantha/Charly conflict to be a bit superficial to say the least. What should have been an inner psychological/philosophical conflict about life and identity became the mere distinction between a sweet schoolteacher with long brown hair who doesn't smoke and a borderline psychopathic 'badass chick' with cropped blond hair who curses, smokes and kills (preferably all at the same time!). Also the changes in the characters attitudes and behavior seem a bit too rushed and forced too me-Mitch for instance, goes from being this totally unscruplous cheat of a detective to being this nice guy who becomes very nearly overprotective of Samantha. And there were about a dozen minor details which weren't made all that clear in the film. Like for instance, how exactly did Charly discover that her 'name' is Samantha Caine in the first place? And why did she sleep with Timothy anyway, seeing as she was going to kill him? The first half of the film was supposed to explain these things, and more, but somehow it ends up being a bit of a drag with all the Christmas scenes and a few somewhat rushed action sequences, not to mention some flashbacks and expositions we're supposed to make some vague sense out of. Its in the second half when the plot really kicks in and we have ourselves a fast-paced thriller that can almost rival any Bond film.On the whole, this film may not be a masterpiece, but its certainly worthy of a try. Just don't keep your expectations TOO high and all will be well...

Review title: Overlooked, under-appreciated, Geena Davis headlining an action flick with Samuel L. Jackson as her wisecracking, foulmouthed sidekick.
Review_body: 1996's The Long Kiss Goodnight was the second movie in a row that director Renny Harlin made with his then-wife Geena Davis. Davis played a pirate in the previous year's Cutthroat Island. Harlin previously directed The Adventures of Ford Fairlane and Die Hard 2 which were edited simultaneously and released just a week apart. Die Hard 2 was a huge hit and Ford Fairlane starred Andrew Dice Clay. Harlin started his career by directing Finland's most expensive film and the slashers Prison and A Nightmare on Elm Street 4: The Dream Master. The screenplay was written by action movie pioneer Shane Black who also wrote Lethal Weapon, Lethal Weapon 2, The Last Boy Scout and The Last Action Hero. Alan Silvestri composed the Original Music and the Cinematography was by Guillermo Navarro.There are rumours and rumours of rumours that a sequel to Renny Harlin's The Long Kiss Goodnight is in the works. I inexplicably missed the original when it came out and dismissed it as just another action flick. I was more than surprised at how prescient a movie it was at the time. The nineties was an adventurous time for filmmaking. Increasingly influenced by music videos, a lot of the art showed dark overtones, in bright colours and quick cuts. Quentin Tarantino's Reservoir Dogs brought a sense of low-budget high-octane fun and breakaway banter back into the movies. He also expanded on the naturalistic acting styles in Barry Levinson's conversational film Diner that let everyday small talk happen while allowing the plot to move along as it might. On the surface, The Long Kiss Goodnight is a fast-paced adventure movie with a quick wit, an accelerating pace, famous locations, and a female hero that performs too many impossible physical feats. Underneath it is an allegory to the growing paranoiac conspiracy theories that are now flooding into the mainstream. The movie references the 1993 World Trade Center bombing and Samantha Caine's transformation into the regrettably-named Charly Baltimore can be seen as an allusion to sleeper-agent multiple personality assassins.

Review title: Superb action film made memorable by touching mother - daughter sub plot
Review_body: I expected The Long Kiss Goodnight to simply be a high octane action thriller delivered at breakneck pace with lots of Samuel L. Jackson dialogue. I was right, but Long Kiss Goodnight give so much more as it included a wonderfully touching sub plot and some wonderful character transitions in Geena Davis' character, all of which she handles superbly. I notice a lot of criticism has been aimed towards this film and I really struggle to understand why there isn't more love for this film. It rates extremely high on the entertainment and, although very far fetched, the plot is conceptually fantastic and well conceived. The general plot is familiar to Timebomb with Michael Biehn and of Bourne Identity with Matt Damon but the mother  daughter sub plot is what really makes this stand out as it is in extreme contrast to the violence and mayhem that is going on.Long Kiss Goodnight begins somewhat unspectacularly with a narration containing mediocre dialogue for exposition purposes but luckily doesn't last particularly long. It would have been better of the narration occurred during the credits but after the patchy start, the film really goes off with a bang. Before you know it, you have just witnessed a car accident complete with blood, fire and a deer with a snapped neck! Harlin does a great job at illustrating the bond between Samantha (Davis) and her daughter before Samantha goes off to discover her past which makes Samantha's relentless transformation in to Charly very surprising to witness. Once Charly has fully emerged, the set pieces never stop and the audience is barely given a chance to breathe. The ending is very climatic and although at is predictable, it by no means is boring! There is also a conspiracy theory that develops throughout the film as the audience are left uninformed regarding the mysterious 'Honeymoon Project' which helps add to the tension.Geena Davis is awesome in this film. She starts as this character with amnesia who reminded me of her character in The Fly, very friendly and happy, and then transforms in to this super sexy bad ass. She pulls off both personalities very convincingly and shows a phenomenal range within this role. People may argue that a role playing a slightly crazed government assassin is easy but the role in its entirety requires a lot of depth. I think this is Geena Davis' best role, more so than Beatlejuice and Thelma and Louise as she was the focal character on a massive scale. I like Samuel L. Jackson but I think he is a victim of his own success as writers and directors like giving him lots of cool dialogue but it often leads to him chewing scenery and taking away from the main point of the film (Pulp Fiction got away with it). Here this doesn't happen as Davis doesn't let him and his character is a lot more sensitive than his usual roles. The rapport between these characters is very effective and gives some light relief to what is going on. Craig Bierko is a great villain he has that innocent charm that makes him look like he wouldn't hurt a fly. He constantly maintains this ice cool exterior despite the fact that his past is catching up with him and disturbing his plans. Yvonne Zima as Samantha's daughter, Caitlin, puts in a very mature performance for a 7 year old and is very effective at pulling at the heart strings of the audience.With the director of Die Hard 2 and the writer of Lethal Weapon on board, Long Kiss Goodnight had a great team behind it and this is why the action is of such great quality. The gratuitous gun play and excessive violence do not disturb at all because everything is so theatrical making it entertaining rather than shocking. There seems to be plenty of evidence of money well spent as I'd much rather see money spent on pyrotechnics and stunt scenes than on CGI. This is what makes it so disappointing that the film did so poorly in the box office.A film that has undeservedly been overlooked, Long Kiss Goodnight is a great, sexy action thriller that has a touching human story embedded in the plot. I could definitely watch this film over and over again, especially if I skip the opening scene. Geena Davis and Samuel L. Jackson both deliver great performances and both give the film a massive attitude. Great film.
